column1: "description": "Politics news articles from The Huffington Post"

column2: Feb 28 (Reuters) - A twin suicide bombing claimed by Islamic State killed 70 people in a Shi'ite district of Baghdad on Sunday in the deadliest attack inside the capital this year
column3:
as militants launched an assault on its western outskirts.


Police sources said the suicide bombers were riding motorcycles and blew themselves up in a crowded mobile phone market in Sadr City
column4:
wounding more than 100 people in addition to the dead.


A Reuters witness saw pools of blood on the ground with slippers
column5: shoes and mobile phones at the site of the blasts
column6:
which was sealed off to prevent further attacks.


In a statement circulated online
column7: Islamic State said it was responsible for the blasts: \"Our swords will not cease to cut off the heads of the rejectionist polytheists
column10:
using derogatory terms for Shi'ite Muslims.


Iraqi forces backed by airstrikes from a U.S.-led coalition have driven Islamic State back in the western Anbar province recently and are preparing for an offensive to retake the northern city of Mosul.


But the militants are still able to strike outside territory they control
column11: often targeting members of Iraq's Shi'ite majority
column12:
most recently on Thursday when two Islamic State suicide bombers killed 15 people at a mosque in the capital.


Prime Minister Haider al-Abadi said the attacks were in response to Islamic State's recent defeats: \"This gang targeted civilians after it lost the initiative and its dregs fled the battlefield before our proud fighters
column13:
\" he said on his official Facebook page.


At dawn on Sunday
column14: suicide bombers and gunmen attacked Iraqi security forces in Abu Ghraib
column15: seizing positions in a grain silo and a cemetery
column16: and killing at least 17 members of the security forces
column17:
officials said.


Security officials blamed Islamic State
column18: and a news agency that supports the group said it had launched a \"wide attack\" in Abu Ghraib
column19:
25 km (15 miles) from the center of Baghdad and next to the international airport.


Footage circulated online by the Amaq news agency appeared to show Islamic State fighters crouching behind dirt berms and launching the attack with automatic rifles
column20:
machine guns and rocket-propelled grenades. Reuters could not verify the video's authenticity.


Security forces had mostly regained control by Sunday evening but officials said there were still clashes.


Baghdad-based security analyst Jasim al-Bahadli said the assault suggested it was premature to declare that Islamic State was losing the initiative in Iraq.


\"Government forces must do a better job repelling attacks launched by Daesh. What happened today could be a setback for the security forces
column22:
using an Arabic acronym for Islamic State.



\u00a0


COUNTER OFFENSIVE


Army and police sources said the militants had attacked from the nearby Islamic State-controlled areas of Garma and Falluja
column23:
driving Humvees and pickup trucks fixed with machine guns.


A curfew was imposed as a regiment of Iraq's elite counter-terrorism forces was mobilized to retake the silo in Abu Ghraib and prevent the militants approaching the nearby airport
column24:
security officials said.


Iraqi army helicopters bombarded Islamic State positions in the and Interior Ministry spokesman Brigadier General Saad Maan said at least 20 militants had been killed in the government's counter offensive.


Fighters from the Hashid Shaabi
column25: a coalition of mainly Iranian-backed Shi'ite militias
column26: were mobilized to Abu Ghraib to reinforce regular government forces in the area
column28:
a local Hashid commander.


Powerful Shi'ite cleric Moqtada al-Sadr also called on fighters loyal to him to be on alert to protect Baghdad. Shi'ite militias like Sadr's 'Peace Brigades' were seen as a bulwark against Islamic State's sweeping advance in 2014 which threatened Iraq's capital and its most sacred Shi'ite shrines.

but may not be distributed on a website.

column1: "title": "ISIS Market Bombing In Baghdad Kills At Least 70 People"

"content": "

New Jersey Gov. Chris Christie (R) had trouble on Sunday explaining his decision to\u00a0endorse Donald Trump's candidacy\u00a0for president in light of his past differences with the Republican front-runner.


On ABC\u2019s \u201cThis Week
column2: \u201d George Stephanopoulos asked Christie question after question about his previous criticism of Trump. Whether it was Trump\u2019s plan to get Mexico to pay for a wall along the United States\u2019 southern border or his pledge to protect Social Security from cuts
column3:
Christie struggled to come up with plausible reasons for supporting a candidate whose positions he once opposed so passionately.


It was a cringe-inducing performance from a governor whose presidential campaign slogan was \"telling it like it is.\"


1. Getting Mexico to pay for the border wall.


Stephanopoulos played a video clip from the campaign trail in which Christie questioned how Trump would get Mexico to build the border wall.


\u201cI tell everybody who goes to a Donald Trump event
column4: if he gets asked a question
column7:
he says he's going to build a wall across the entire border between the United States and Mexico. How? How is he going to make the Mexicans pay for the wall? How? They are a sovereign nation.\u201d


Christie said he now believes Trump is capable of convincing Mexico to do it
column8:
\u00a0and that Trump has enough time before the election to \u201canswer\u201d how he would accomplish that goal.\u00a0


\"You know
column10: this is a February -- this is February of a campaign
column13:
this is a February -- this is February of a campaign.
New Jersey Gov. Chris Christie (R)


Stephanopoulos pressed Christie
column14:
noting that the presidential campaign has been under way for eight months.


Christie vaguely offered that Trump would get it done through \u201cdiplomacy and other tools
column15:
\u201d and emphasized the real estate mogul\u2019s \u201cstrong leadership.\u201d


\u201cStrong leadership is able to exert those things and be able to talk to folks about what advantages and disadvantages are of certain policies
column16:
\u201d Christie said. \u201cThe fact of the matter is that there won't be any question about Mr. Trump's strength and his resoluteness in terms of getting the things done that he's wanted to get done.\u201d


When Stephanopoulos did not let up
column17: pushing Christie to offer specific ways Trump could realize his goal
column18:
\u00a0Christie finally settled on the prospect of leveraging the U.S.\u2019 trading relationship with Mexico.


\u201cListen
column19: I think what he's talked about is the trade relationship and working on the trade relationship and he talked about that yesterday
column20:
\u201d Christie said. \u201cAnd using that as a lever to get them to do things on immigration.\u201d



2. Not cutting Social Security.


Stephanopoulos went on to ask Christie what he thought of Trump\u2019s opposition to cutting Social Security benefits
column21:
something Christie had openly embraced in his straight talk-themed presidential run. The host played another clip of Christie on the stump mocking Trump\u2019s promise not to cut the popular social insurance program.\u00a0


\u201cI think that we need to do something on Social Security
column22: \u201d Christie told the host. \u201cAnd I've made that really clear. And so listen
column23:
Donald Trump and I are not going to agree on every issue.\u201d


Stephanopoulos again asked for a better explanation
column24:
saying Christie\u2019s support for cutting benefits for future beneficiaries was the \u201csignature issue\u201d of his campaign.


\u201cIt's not the signature issue of my campaign
column25: \u201d Christie retorted. \u201cThe signature issue of my campaign was national security
column26:
keeping America safe and secure from terrorist attacks and making us a better ally and neighbor around the world.\u201d


Christie even argued that Trump\u2019s plan was no less fantastical than the other Republican candidates'.


\u201cThe fact of the matter is
column28: when you look up on that stage
column29: no one else has a plan on Social Security
column31:
\u201d Christie said.


\u201cWhat I'm saying is that he's going to give more complete answers as time goes on on these issues
column32:
\u201d he added. \u201cLet's hold every candidate to that same standard.\u201d



What I'm saying is that he's going to give more complete answers as time goes on on these issues.
New Jersey Gov. Chris Christie (R)


In fact
column33: Trump\u2019s top rivals for the GOP nomination
column34:
Sens. Marco Rubio (R-Fla.) and Ted Cruz (R-Texas) both have plans to alter Social Security that are more detailed -- and more closely resemble what Christie had proposed as a candidate -- than anything Trump has put forward.


Rubio would raise the retirement age for claiming full benefits above 67 --\u00a0something that is already scheduled to happen --\u00a0reduce benefits for \u201cupper-income\u201d seniors and adopt a more modest cost-of-living adjustment.


Cruz has embraced similar proposals and gone further
column35:
expressing support for partial privatization of the program.


Trump
column37: has said he would close Social Security\u2019s funding gap without cutting benefits by growing the economy and cracking down on \u201cwaste
column38:
fraud and abuse.\u201d


The\u00a0AARP says\u00a0Trump is the one candidate in the presidential race -- in either party -- who has yet to lay out a concrete plan for the program.



Thx @marcorubio for thanking @AARPSC for #TakeAStand on #SocialSecurity & for sharing ur plan at rally #SCPolitics pic.twitter.com/tZ6nj6XTYq

\u2014 Pete Jeffries (@petejeffries) February 18
column39:
2016


3. Banning Muslims from entering the country


The difficult questions did not stop there for Christie. Christie was at pains to explain how he reconciled his apparent disagreement with Trump\u2019s proposal to ban Muslims from entering the United States with his current backing of the candidate.


He first insisted that because Trump had modified his proposed ban to exclude U.S. citizens
column40:
it was now acceptable.


Then he argued the ban was less important than Trump\u2019s \u201coverall\u201d tough stance on national security
column41: which was evident in his support for mass surveillance
column42:
a \u201cstronger\u201d military and the police.


\u201cMr. Trump has talked about the idea of making sure we restore NSA authority
column43: he's -- which some people in this race have not been in favor of
column45: \u201d Christie said. \u201cHe has stood up and said that he wants to make our military stronger
column46:
which we need to do. He's stood up for law enforcement in ways that other candidates in this race have not done.\u201d



4. Accusing New Jersey Muslims of celebrating Sept. 11.


Christie was again caught flat-footed when Stephanopoulos asked whether Trump\u2019s claim he saw Muslim Americans in New Jersey celebrating the Sept. 11
column47:
2001 attacks was a \u201cslander\u201d of Christie\u2019s constituents.


\u201cI don't think he means it as that at all
column48: as a slander of my state's citizens
column51: is when I say he's -- can be trusted
column55:
and I've seen that over the course of a 14-year relationship with him.\u201d


Christie\u2019s embrace of Trump is notable since
column57: he specifically spoke out against judging all Muslim Americans for the actions of a few extremists. At one New Hampshire campaign appearance
column58: Christie touted his nomination of Sohail Mohammed
column60: as a judge in New Jersey
column61:
and his outreach to the state\u2019s large Muslim population.


Several times on Sunday
column62: Christie gave up trying to explain his support for Trump\u2019s policies
column63:
talking up his electability instead.


\u201cGiven the other options on the stage
column66: best guy to be our nominee to beat Hillary Clinton and to be the next president of the United States
column67:
\u201d he concluded.

column68: and use is subject to our terms. It may be used for personal consumption
column69:
but may not be distributed on a website.











"

column1: "contentSnippet": " New Jersey Gov. Chris Christie (R) had trouble on Sunday explaining his decision to endorse Donald Trump's ..."
"title": "Chris Christie Struggles To Explain Trump Endorsement In Train Wreck TV Interview"

"content": "

WASHINGTON -- Hillary Clinton had a great night on Saturday. The Democratic Party had a terrible one.


Clinton trounced Sen. Bernie Sanders by nearly 3-to-1 in the South Carolina primary
column2: winning every single county in the state. The thumping followed a convincing Clinton victory in the Nevada caucuses less than a week earlier
column3: and sets the stage for a strong showing for Clinton on Super Tuesday
column4:
when 11 states are in play.


For the Democratic Party establishment
column5: these wins are being interpreted as a sign that the universe is back in order
column6: after a 74-year-old democratic socialist from Vermont had seemingly knocked everything out of orbit. Party leaders long ago picked Clinton as their standard-bearer for 2016 and worked to clear the field of potential primary challengers. When Sanders began closing on Clinton in national polls and clobbered her in New Hampshire
column7: the establishment bet was starting to look shaky. Had they lost touch with the core concerns of the party's base? After South Carolina
column8:
Sanders' chances to secure an upset nomination are dwindling.


Exit polling showed that Clinton won every demographic tracked except voters under 30. Even here
column9: she was far more competitive with Sanders than in prior contests
column10:
losing just 54 percent to 46 percent. She even won a higher share of the black vote than Barack Obama did in 2008.


But Democratic Party elites shouldn't be high-fiving each other. They should be very
column11:
very worried.


In primary after primary this cycle
column12: Democratic voters just aren't showing up. Only 367
column13: 491 people cast a ballot for either Clinton or Sanders on Saturday. That's down 16 percent from the 436
column14: 219 people who came out in 2008 for Clinton and Obama. Factor in the 93
column15: 522 people who voted for John Edwards back in the day
column16:
and you can see the scope of the problem. Democrats in 2016 are only getting about two-thirds of the primary votes that they received eight years ago.


Republican turnout in the South Carolina primary
column18:
was up more than 70 percent from 2008.


South Carolina's turnout numbers are not an anomaly. They're consistent with other primaries to date. Republicans are psyched. Democrats are demoralized.


Presidential elections increasingly hinge on each party's ability to turn out the faithful. There simply are not many truly independent voters who cast their ballots for different parties in different cycles. A big chunk of voters who identify as independents do so not because they cherish a moderate middle ground between two parties
column19: but because they see their own party as insufficiently committed to its ideological principles. In this era
column20:
lousy primary turnout spells big trouble for the general election.


The poor Democratic turnout figures are not an indictment of Clinton alone. Maybe the DNC's decision to bury the party's debates on weekends and holidays helped Republicans generate more early enthusiasm with primetime coverage.\u00a0And part of Sanders' pitch
column22: is his insistence that progressive energy will bring out high numbers of enthusiastic voters that an old party insider just can't compete with. It's a good pitch. But so far
column23:
it isn't happening.


It's always hard to motivate voters for four more years of the same old thing after getting eight years of it -- especially when many of those years were mired in an awful recession
column24:
followed by a weak economic recovery. Opposition parties typically have a better hand after eight years. That's why 12-year runs in the presidency by a single party don't happen very often.


If Republicans nominate Donald Trump for president -- and barring a cataclysm or a coup
column25:
they will -- there will be plenty of energized Democrats who turn out in the general election for no other reason than to cast a ballot against a billionaire who has predicated his campaign on raw bigotry.


That will help even the energy some. But the flip side of the coin is that lots of angry white people will show up to vote for Trump. We know because they're already doing so in the primaries. And a lot of Republican partisans who prefer other candidates still care more about turning the page on the Obama era than they do about Trump's flirtations with fascism (and even
column27:
liberal critiques of GOP orthodoxy).


Trump's overtly racist campaign makes it hard to see how he wins Western swing states like Nevada or New Mexico that have high numbers of Latino voters. But his economic pitch to the white working class holds obvious appeal in traditional Democratic strongholds in the upper Midwest -- communities that have been ravaged by the past three decades of U.S. economic policy. Even if Trump lost every other swing state in the country
column28:
turning the Rust Belt red would be enough for him to win the Electoral College.


That's a difficult maneuver. But it's time to start worrying about President Trump.


Zach Carter is a co-host of the HuffPost Politics podcast "So
column29:
That Happened."\u00a0Subscribe here or listen to the latest episode below:\u00a0

column30: and use is subject to our terms. It may be used for personal consumption
column31:
but may not be distributed on a website.











"

column1: "contentSnippet": " WASHINGTON -- Hillary Clinton had a great night on Saturday. The Democratic Party had a terrible one. Clinton trounced Sen. ..."
"title": "Democrats Should Be Very Nervous About Their Terrible Turnout Numbers"

"content": "

Sen. Marco Rubio (R-Fla.) says it's unfair for surrogates to know about his accomplishments before they endorse his presidential campaign.


When "Fox News Sunday" host Chris Wallace asked him about the matter
column2:
the senator explained the surrogates were unfamiliar with his resume due to the fact they were\u00a0"signing up at the last second."



WALLACE: Senator
column3: why can't officials who support you
column4: who come out to endorse you
column5:
name a specific accomplishment of your time in the Senate?

RUBIO: Well
column7:
they're signing up at the last second. They're inspired by our message. They want to be part of our team. We haven't provided them all the information. I'm more than happy to tell you about my record.



The first-term senator's thin record has already been the target of attacks from Democrats and Republicans alike. It didn't do much to help Rubio's campaign
column9:
when several of his surrogates struggled to name a single achievement that bolstered his case for the presidency.


Rep. Cresent Hardy (R-Nev.) most recently\u00a0failed to answer a question from an MSNBC host
column10: instead noting the senator had "been running for a presidential race most of this year." After former Pennsylvania Sen. Rick Santorum (R) dropped out of the presidential race earlier this year
column11:
he too was unable to name\u00a0any of Rubio's accomplishments.

but may not be distributed on a website.
